In the rules department, you can look at http://www.4chan.org/rules - all global and board specific rules are in full effect. Apart from that, only two rules are important.

1. BE EXCELLENT TO EACH OTHER.
2. PARTY ON, DUDES. (AND DUDETTES)

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>86794162
The token gets placed where the model was, there are no restrictions about engangement range.
After the succesful reanimation you place the animated model as close as you can to the token while not being in close combat.
If you fail to reanimate you leave the token where it was.

Augustine's The City Of God and Christian Doctrine, Book 16, Chapter 8. - Whether Certain Monstrous Races of Men are Derived from the Stock of Adam or Noahs Sons

It is also asked whether we are to believe that certain monstrous races of men, spoken of in secular history, have sprung from Noahs sons, or rather, I should say, from that one man from whom they themselves were descended. For it is reported that some have one eye in the middle of the forehead; some, feet turned backwards from the heel; some, a double sex, the right breast like a man, the left like a woman, and that they alternately beget and bring forth: others are said to have no mouth, and to breathe only through the nostrils; others are but a cubit high, and are therefore called by the Greeks "Pigmies:" they say that in some places the women conceive in their fifth year, and do not live beyond their eighth. So, too, they tell of a race who have two feet but only one leg, and are of marvellous swiftness, though they do not bend the knee: they are called Skiopodes, because in the hot weather they lie down on their backs and shade themselves with their feet. Others are said to have no head, and their eyes in their shoulders; and other human or quasi-human races are depicted in mosaic in the harbor esplanade of Carthage, on the faith of histories of rarities. What shall I say of the Cynocephali, whose dog-like head and barking proclaim them beasts rather than men? But we are not bound to believe all we hear of these monstrosities. But whoever is anywhere born a man, that is, a rational, mortal animal, no matter what unusual appearance he presents in color, movement, sound, nor how peculiar he is in some power, part, or quality of his nature, no Christian can doubt that he springs from that one protoplast. We can distinguish the common human nature from that which is peculiar, and therefore wonderful.

What is it about the Elysian Drop Troops that make the 40k masses not like them? I am just baffled at this point its impossible to get them.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>86793676
Depends on the size of the battlefield you where fighting on. They came out when Apocalypse sized games where popular, so twelve feet or eighteen foot battlefields, in which the armies tried to outmanever each other where perfect for them, as they could quicky seize key areas instead of the usual IG slow trudge across the table. They were also handy for shooting up rear arer artillery and vehicles - dropping a load of melta guns and demo charges behind the enemies tanks or HQ was good fun. But, yeah, like real paratroopers, they didnt last long once they dropped. They where a light strike force for complimenting the typical IG plodding Steamroller.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>86781014
When they came out, the fluff that accompanied them, instead of bigging them up as the best thing ever (as happens today) instead told a load of stories about how they were massacred every time they dropped. Also, they didnt get any super powercreeped weapons to make them better than the normal Guard, like every release nowadays seems to do. Because of this, (and the god awful price for each figure), they didnt sell that well. I had a friend who started collecting them, but after he had brought a couple of squads and then saw how many orks I could afford for the same price, he gave up on them and started on Nid swarms instead.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: Elysians were, ironically, too 'sci-fi' for the sci-fi setting. A lot of the draw of the Guard is that they're using some future tech, but their aesthetic is that of pre-digital age gunpowder armies. Pretty much anything Napoleonic to early/mid Cold War. The Elysians didn't fit into that. Their packs don't resemble as 'parachute pack' enough for people to catch that visually, and their helmet design was generic. The only visually redeeming thing about the Elysians are their vehicles and their unique lasguns. Shit on that opinion all you want, but there's a reason why they never got off the ground...pun intended.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>86793300
Worm's entire thing is that the setting - Brockton Bay - is a type of sandbox region in which all the characters have well-defined personalities, and all of them want to fucking murder each other, with clearly delineated faction politics and personal capabilities. People read it for, essentially, the same reason people read A Song Of Ice And Fire/Game of Thrones; a bunch of powerful, petty assholes attempting to murder each other in a rapidly deteriorating setting. There's catharsis in that.

There's also the fact that a lot of people resonate with the main character, because she's got a versatile ability that doesn't lend itself directly well to solving threats through main force, so she often gets creative, and more than a little ruthless at times. You know how a lot of people go "X should have used their power in Y way, that would have solved this whole situation"? She appeals deeply to theorycrafters who like to figure out how a particular power could be used to win a potential fight. It helps that Taylor is a girl that's been bullied and hurt, so seeing her rise to a position of power is a big emotional payoff for a lot of readers.

Worm's got good points. The problem is there's a lot of shit to slog through to get those good points.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
I’ve been trying to design a 3d6 based system for a while now. I came up with the idea that, since the rolls are weighted to fall into a specific range, I wanted to factor that in and keep bonuses to a minimum. As such, using a rolling higher is better system, I came up with a number to succeed system for saves and skill checks and such. For instance, a simple task requires a 7, a trying requires a 10, a difficult requires a 13, a hard requires a 16, an inhuman a 19, and an impossible requires 21. So the difficulty of something is divided into tiers, 1-6. However, without +1s and such you may be wondering how you can roll higher than 18. Which is where this maybe gets confusing.

The idea I had is that your stat and skills are what determine how difficult something actually is in practice. I figure stats go from 1-5, with buffs/magic/skills being able to boost this to up to 6. Average for a stat would be 3, 4 is above average, 5 is top 5% tier, 6 represents superhuman. 7 and above would be reserved specifically for enemies (giants would have a strength score of 7 for instance but I’m getting off topic). For each point above 3, the difficulty of a check would be reduced by 1 tier, and conversely for each point below 3 it is increased. Anything that gets reduced to tier 0 is now an automatic success, so someone with 6 body would be able to do feats of strength considered impossible with a roll of 13 or higher, slightly better than 1 in 4 odds, but would be able to Hard tasks with a roll of only 7 or better, succeeding almost 3/4ths of the time and not having to roll to succeed at anything easier than hard. Is this system intuitive do you think? I’ve gotten mixed reception with the idea, it is a bit muddy, perhaps. Should I just abandon this idea and go for a simple 3d6+modifiers with fixed to hit numbers instead?

I was torn on what to remain, enter or leave. Enter means you get instant value, but leave lets you double up on his - and also makes destroying your boardstate an issue. I like leaves since you get value when you have the creature and attack with it as well as a bonus with the + for when it dies.

>Demographics:

Humans – Make up most of the region’s population. Most are technically Westerlings, but some coastal tribes also have significant Northman ancestry.

Swamp Creatures – The followers of Norn, a daughter of the Bog-Witch, frequently raid the Bayukmen.

Miscellaneous Fey – A few swamp oriented fey not associated with the Bog-Witch live in the Bayukmen lands, including uncorrupted versions of swamp gnomes and kikimora. They keep a low profile though as nearly any fey found in Bayukmen lands will likely be considered a spy of Norn and attacked.

>Religion:

The Bayukmen worship the Ancestor Trees. Believed by many scholars to be a different interpretation of the elven creator god, worship of the Ancestor Trees mostly consists of individual rituals and prayers held at well hidden groves where faces have been carved into old trees.

Some aspects of the Northmen Pantheon can also be found among the beliefs of the tribes with Northman ancestry.

The Lady of the Woods has some followers in the area, mostly folk from the Land of Windmills living in the lands bordering Bayukmen territory. It is unclear whether she is a faerie lord or something darker, and even more unclear if she associated with the Bog-Witch. Generally the Bayukmen attack her followers though, seeing them as likely vassals of the Bog-Witch.

The Bog-Witch and Norn are worshipped by their followers who intrude into Bayukmen lands. A few Bayukmen traitors have also been known to ally with them.

A few non-humans in the region follow minor faerie lords or stranger beings.

>Military:

Bayukmen tend to be small and poorly equipped, and also have a distrust of magic. Despite these disadvantages, they have driven off countless raids and invasions with ruthlessly underhand warfare. Common tactics include constructing traps, springing ambushes, using poisoned weapons, and luring enemies into local wildlife (which are nearly as dangerous as those in the Bog-Witch's lands).

<<<<<<<< READ THE PDF BEFORE ASKING WHERE TO START

GURPS is a modular, adaptable system, capable of running a wide range of characters, settings, and play styles with level of detail varying from lightweight to completely autistic.
Optional rules allow you to emulate different genres with a single system, even switching genres within a single game.

A nearly complete archive of GURPS books can be found by those who pay attention to file extensions.
Never post direct links to the archive anywhere.

If you're wondering where to start:
The Basic Set covers everything, including a lot of optional rules you probably won't use.
A genre guide can be found in the archive, under Unofficial > GURPSgen. It tells you what extra books and articles you may find useful for many common genres.
How To be a GURPS GM is a good read even for players.
GCS (gurpscharactersheet.com) is an excellent character builder software with page references to all the books and the option to export to both Foundry and Fantasy Grounds.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
So I've been hearing for the last 8 years on /tg/ how OP wizards are in 3.5, and I always laughed at and chuckled along in a number of threads, but this past year, I've had the chance to play 3.5 with two different groups, and I gotta say...I was extremely unimpressed.

GROUP 1
We had 1 Wizard, 1 Cleric, 1 Paladin, and a Ranger. We started out at level 5 and managed to get up to level 10, and were currently in the midst of an espionage campaign, secretly scouting out terrain for an army so they could ambush an enemy kingdom's keep and begin an invasion. Wizard cast Invisibility and Fly on himself, and began scouting terrain. We thought he was in the clear, until we realized "Oh yea, this is a magic heavy game", and saw Griffon's begin heading directly towards him. We didn't know how or why until much later when it was revealed that an enemy Cleric had cast "Scry" on the Wizard and was tracking him. And because Griffon's have "scent", and the Wizard was 300 feet in the air, they only had to be in the general vicinity of him to find out where he was. We watched as our Wizard, who stood there thinking they would fly right past him, got torn to pieces by their talons. As they succinctly finished with him after only 2 rounds of combat.

I've started working on the 1.0 version. It includes:
- four standard classes: Warrior (Fighter), Witch (Wizard), Priest (Cleric), Pariah (Thief)
- reworked the task resolution system
- combat is more tactical, detailed
- reworked all weapons, armour
- gamified most, if not all, skill checks so that it is not just 'roll a d6', think of it as a mini 'dice placement' game. List of gamified skills: forage, fish, hunt and track and set traps, harvest, arcanum, brew (potion or posion), bless, enchant, lockpick, pick pocket, climb, etc.
- laid the foundation for crafting system
- set the basics of trading (a chance to be a merchant)
- potion making is gamified, with two versions Arcanum and Herbalism, includes poisons (combat toxins) as well
- reworked the fantasy creatures
- added 'scars' for going zero HP
- added 'corruption' for failing at magic use and soulstone handling
- added ZEAL which modifies spelluse
- magic item creation is 'gamified' with blessed and enchanted items created by Priests and Witches respectively
- created a "quest generator seeds" table
- Worked on weather to make it more realistic
- detailed overland actions 'surveying' is the main exploration for a hex
- detailed dungeon delving 'searching' is the main exploration for a chamber in a point of interest
- added company play which is basically a separate mini-game for you to play once you establish your company (a cult, a covenant, a band of thieves, etc.)
- added faction play
- reworked alignment, now you start as NEUTRAL and your deeds shift your alignment either way.
- added tons of items

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>86786880
the usual thinking with this is that the *reason* they went for titans and plane games isn't just to milk the epic market, but because those are on the right side of the 3D-print value equation, where tanks and infantry would not be.

basically, plastic scales better (in quantity) but it also scales better in size. so for large, complicated models like a titan, it's both technically more challenging to print and also more expensive in materials. it might cost $15 to print a titan vs $85 to buy it, and while that seems like a lot, it's not enough to make someone who has always stuck with regular models and is hesitant about 3D printing make the jump. The difference doesn't cover the cost of a printer, and it's intimidating to start.
Small, high-detail things though, is where the tech shines. It's comparatively very easy for even a beginner to print them, and they use far less material. GW might sell an epic space marine company for $50, where it would cost $2 to print. and the printer can knock out multiple such companies in an afternoon.

suddenly the balance is broken. just supplying your own army covers the cost of the printer, and one printer could effortlessly supply an entire club with armies for nominal cost. and once people get carried away with that, they'll just start printing everything. obviously that isn't something GW wants, so they've been pushing the other direction, in all their games - toward larger, heavier, more complicated models.

Red Surface:
Sala watched as the Equatorial ocean moved below, a straight yellowed line that extended forwards and back forever. Clouds could be seen more as faint shadows upon the surface, the air still far too thin to support the great thunderheads of Venus. Along its shore like scores of desperate beasts the bulky structures of Arcology wilderness extended outward, the long rows of extractors churning the effluvia into a foaming mist as the machines filtered out useful material. For a moment there was peace, the pilot silently communicating with the craft that had taken them through the fray and so close to landing on Mars itself.
But peace is always short lived. The drop craft jerked violently as its instinctive neuralware fired a series of thrusters to throw them into a wild arc. Sala extended three of her arms to brace herself as the martian surface careened around them. Glimpses of crumbling arcology spires, sprawling residential creep, factories and mantle taps all in a few seconds as the pilot tried to wrest control back from the frightened machine. She could trace the trajectories of what had frightened the craft, several rapidly accelerating rods. Optical organoids traced their vectors, a second pass was coming. Sala extended one arm, letting its full length easily brush against the pilot in his neural harness. The connection was brief, her thoughts sent along the wire at a shallow level like a single pluck of a string tied between them, danger.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>86789973
In my experience the best marks for balance are "why would a player choose this over something else" (easy) and "why would a player choose something else over this" (much harder). You want to make options, not defaults. It's fine for your custom concepts to be interesting, powerful, synergistic; but they need to have gaps or else you're just bulldozing the rest of character customization. Ideally this is one feat among many, one item in an arsenal, one character in a party. It should not solve every problem and it should never be without opportunity cost.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>86766305
More races doesn't necessarily make a setting better or more interesting. In fact, starting from a perspective of "how can I be better or different from another popular author that writes things in my same setting" is a cuck mindset. What matters is why the elements you DO write exist, how they interconnect, and how they coexist. Settings are just flavor, anyway---they are the backdrop upon which a story occurs, and most people really don't give much of a shit about that backdrop.

Right now I'm running a Pathfinder 1e game that takes place pretty much exclusively in a custom version of the underdark. Society is in the midst of an industrial revolution, but lots of technology has already been replaced because the entirety of the civilized population has access to magic which circumvents the need for a lot of nonmagical tech. The primary races are a handful of subspecies of dark elf, a sociopathic race of anthropomorphic spider people, and a few subraces of goblin. There are a few other small ones, but you don't need a thousand races to make an interesting setting.

last_replies.com:
I posted this in the last thread but couldn't answer the replies in time.

>Fantastic yellow, how did you do it?
Prime grey. Layer evenly with Vallejo model color Yellow Ochre (70.913). Yellow Ochre has amazing coverage and is easy to use.
Cover with Vallejo game ink Yellow (72.085). This gives it a bright, popping yellow colour. When the ink is dry, carefully highlight the edges and raised areas with Vallejo model colour Dark Sand (70.847). Finally, I use a tiny brush to apply Citadel Seraphim Sepia, but only through the recesses.

>Have you washed black parts Anon?
Nope, just layered black to grey.

>Any fluff?
The Sunbats Mercenary Company was devised in the dying days of the Third Succession War as deniable Lyran assets to harass Combine worlds after the peace treaty. The officer in charge of the scheme, Leutnant-General Leerkopf, realised that he had erroneously assigned green infantry recruits as his new mechwarriors only after they had been defeated in their inaugural battle against a smaller force of pirates. But with his career and reputation in the balance, Leerkopf channeled his vast family wealth as well as Commonwealth funds to ensure their success.

A training exercise with dummy rounds and low-powered lasers, designed to make mechwarriors of these infantrymen, nevertheless resulted in a 17% casualty rate when the company traversed through an artificial lake and two mechwarriors had failed to correctly close their hatches.

The more gross incompetence demonstrated by the Sunbats, the more they were funded and subsidised by an increasingly desperate Leerkopf. Leerkopf did make one excellent staffing decision, one of his aides was an outstanding accountant and bureaucrat who was able to reallocate and misappropriate vast resources to prevent the Sunbats from crossing over the brink of failure.

Thus the worst mercenary company ever assembled failed their way to become a battalion, and somewhat competent, within seven years of their founding.

Released in November 2017, Genesys is a pen-and-paper generic/universal RPG system and toolkit by Fantasy Flight Games and EDGE Studio, using a refined version of the system presented by their Star Wars RPGs (Edge of the Empire, Age of Rebellion, Force and Destiny). last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>86788928
Read Ryuutama. Has a good exploration system. To TL;DR it, they pick where to go. They roll for travel and direction. Of they fail hard enough they might get hurt or lost, which would lead them in the wrong direction. Don't give them a map, let them draw one themselves. Maybe give them basic positions of cities and stuff already pre-dawn, mayne some roads. But if they choose to go off-road, they can certainly discover hidden places. Maybe it's just pretty. Describe that. More often such hard to get, hidden places should have something. A tomb, an enemy, a treasure. Something memorable and unique they won't find anywhere else in the campaign. And yes, you can give them a super powerful treasure of their rolls are good enough and their decisions smart enough. Going up the snow covered mountain isn't a good idea unless you have the proper equipment.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>86788928
Few things that immediately come to mind:

AD&D Wilderness and Dungeon Survival Guides, great for ideas in a fantasy exploration setting. Maybe the 3.5 Stormwrack/Frostburn/Sandstorm books could be useful as well.

From Here to There is nine all-new adventures focused on traveling from point A to point B.

As for making the exploration part fun, first off you want to have there be things to see. You don't need to go Tolkien and have a backstory on every tree branch but you want to have things be broken up with points of change. Have it be an open field towards a tree line and then in the trees have there be a river or a cliff's edge that needs to be dealt with as a traversal problem in some way. You can also put in some open world style adventure points. From Here to There will deal with some things like that, but a cave opening or ruined temple can give a distraction to explore if they're not on a time crunch. Look at discovering something in Skyrim. Also add in time of day and weather as exploring in the rain at night is different than during the day in calm weather.

Encounters, think about the things that live (and lived) there and how they would use the space. If there are no people in the area now, were there before? Ruins of civilization, be it an old trap fence for catching animals or some housing that hasn't broken down, this gives a feeling 'this place wasn't just put here for us'. Also, prey and predator animals, have some rabbits looking for food in the woods, a lizard sunning itself on a rock in a desert, maybe even see a hawk dive down and catch a field mouse in a clearing. This can show the place as alive without needing it to be all 'Okay, some wolves attack'.

If you want to add a 'realism' touch to the exploration which may vary from system to system, video game Miasmata has the player do triangulation of waypoints to fill out the map. There are various videos and guides for this, and can help the players identify points of interest.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Many of us know the usual Blood War gimmick in a D&D context: demons and devils clashing on a massive and multiversal scale, often using whole mortal worlds as their battlefields. There might be yugoloths running around as some mix of mercenaries, profiteers, and manipulators. (In Eberron, this might instead be a clash between multiple simultaneously released fiendish overlords, some of which did not quite get along.)

But what if we add a wild card to the mix, something none of these fiends even remotely expect? Desperate times call for desperate measures. When the whispers of cosmic, aberrant powers promise salvation to a besieged world, who is to refuse them? Whether these eldritch forces are Mak Thuum Ngatha and Ragnorra, Caiphon and Allabar, Dyrrn and Belashyrra, Cthulhu and Shub-Niggurath, or some other mix of entities, they are willing to empower vast cults and lend a hand against the fiendish invaders. (In 13th Age, the Crusader wages war against demons, and the "dark gods" he is pledged to could very well be aberrant!) What happens if the fiends are driven away? Well, the world can work that out later, right?

As an alternative scenario, it could be that the forces originally plaguing the world are spooky aberrations to begin with. Then, fiendish powers start to offer their aid, establishing cults across the globe to drive back all the tentacles and extraneous eyeballs.

How would you run an adventure or a campaign which pits fiends (no pun intended) and aberrations against one another? What sort of interesting scenarios could PCs get involved in?

>>86793115
Ryuutama is pretty good if you enjoy traveling games. There was a guy shilling it left and right (probably ironically making fun of another guy looking back at it). The aforementioned guy who was being made fun of did some math about how it has perfect scaling and bonuses, but I don't give a shit. I'd actually recommend Fabula Ultima if you want a more combat focused game, rather than a travel focused on, or just combine them.
I did so recently. The stats are equivalent anyways. Choose one FU class as your class and one Ryuutama class as your background. Choose the type to add some bonuses. I prefer keeping the Ryuutama HP/MP, and just divide the MP cost of FU spells cost by 5, rounded up. Combat is from FU (way deadlier using Ryuutama stats), travel from Ryuutama. When you level you get a skill point to spend in your or another class as per FU, and all the Ryuutama level based stuff. Max level is 10. So if you multiclass you are gaining a breath of options but won't get access to the ultimate from FU.
Ignore the starting level 5 and mandatory multiclassing from FU, ignore the bonus class/type and combat actions gained at level 2 from Ryuutama.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>86783492
>>86788723
Now I'm not an expert on game design, but I like what you've done, though I still have my reservations. The mounted abilities are all cool and the class itself seems more on theme than the fighter subclass. I like the flanking maneuver as an option for when you're unmounted but apart from that it doesn't have a lot outside riding and feels a lot more narrowly focused than the fighter, especially when 5e did a decent job fleshing out the other not-quite-fighter classes.
As for the subclasses
>Great Knight
This looks like the other half of the fighters cavalier subclass, the "mmo tank" half. It has a lot of game-y features which I'm not personally into but that's not unprecedented in 5e. Could do with a bit more chivalric flavour.
>Troubadour
It just borrows a lot of bard features and I don't see much to gain from it that you wouldn't gain by just multiclassing with a bard. If anything, I think a mounted bard college would work better than a bard-like cavalier kit.
>Volleyman
Out of all the subclasses this is my favourite because it's thematically tied to its mount. I like all its opportunities for extra attacks but I feel like it could use some features related to mobility for variety.
>Dark Knight
This one's the worst in my eyes. It doesn't meaningfully incorporate the mount in it's theme or mechanics. (how does sitting on a horse get rid of enemies resistances?) It just gets a lot of edgy features that I feel would be more at home as part of a warlock kit or something.
Overall I feel like there's a lack of a cohesive theme between the subclasses, maybe your intention was to make up for the base class' lack of unmounted abilities but the subclasses just end up feeling unconnected to being a Cavalier. I know you said you're not doing any sweeping changes, but this is what I'd be the most interested in changing.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>86788985
> how to get players to care about things
Make them useful, make them a haven. I give automatic (or improved) rolls for near everything, when you spend time in a settlement. Resting is free, levelling up is free, and so is partying - you automatically get the benefits from these, so long as you’re staying in town.

Well.. kind of. Instead of rolling to succeed, you’re rolling on an event table. And instead of adding your stats, you add the settlement’s. A seedy town is going to be a bad place to chill with the locals, while an industrious city is going to be excellent for finding work.

> go out ad do things to make it better
These stats aren’t just abstract numbers, they’re built up from resources that actively contribute. Farmer Flentor counts towards his farm’s Goowdill. The local guards, plus their watchtower, add up to a decent Safety. It makes stats personal - personified. A player can build a bakery, or organise a holiday, or erect a statue to the gods; and they’ll mechanically see the difference in the quality of their downtime.

Events also reference and change these resources, giving it a life of its own.

>>86791141
Depends on the setting. In LotR the Half Elf chooses whether to become a full Elf or a full Human. In WoW, as few as there are, there really isn't a difference. In FR they grow up at the same rate.
The issue I often don't see considered is perception of time. We see it at about 60 FPS, sound included. Cats at 120, dogs at 90. Some animals see it as high as 250+, elephants as low as 15. This is tested with a pulsing light. How fast does it have to go until it's seen as just a constant light and no blinking? Same with hearing actually. A sound with breaks until it's just the same sound. So how fast would Elves go? In most they have Human perception of time. Fair enough. Similar metabolism. But what if they lived longer because their metabolic rate was ten times slower? That would have so many implications on Elven physiology and perception of time. They could recognize weather patterns because to them an hour is like our minute. They could remember faces a century after because to them only a year has passed.
At the same time decline in society would happen. If they existed millenia before any other race they would be able to advance, but would be outstripped in a few centuries by other races simply because they perceive time so vastly differently.
And what of other races? Dwarves? Orcs? Goblins? Are Goblins like flies where for them the year they've been alive is actually decades?
Obviously the answer to all of this is magic. But really it's an interesting thing to think about.

my setting doesn't really have good Gods or evil Gods, only the Heavens, which is both a dimension and a sapient being which rules over Fate and commands Gods to maintain the world, and the Hells, which are an infinite number of dimensions each designed to punish sinners in an appropriate manner, and is managed solely by the Judges, who decided how long X sinner ought to be punished and in what way
humans often get short and simplistic punishments, although powerful spirits, gods and other immortal beings can get very extreme and very long punishments, not because of a difference in sin, but because the Judges take into account how much punishment someone can take before their mind breaks, so where a sinful human would get do to do moderately physically painful and repetitive tasks for about 10 years with breaks every weekend (alongside nightly sleep) before reincarnating, a God who is being punished for the exact same sins would get to do tasks a 100 times harder for a 1000 years straight with no breaks and no sleep
If you do good, you just reincarnate immediately. If do something amazing, you reincarnate into the Heavens as a minor God.
People don't worship any Gods, they only pray to the Heavens in its entirety. You don't say "By the Gods!", but you might say "By Heaven!" or just "Heavens!"
Heaven isn't particularly evil but it isn't particularly good either, the phrase "kill 1 person secretly and you are a murderer, kill 100 soldiers in war and you are a hero" applies to its judgements for example

>>86786321
I’m looking for a good name for an enchanted archipelago of tropical islands that can’t be found by normal means. What do you think I should do?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>86791613
>can’t be found by normal means
If that means no natives, then honestly something extremely 'generic' would be the most 'realistic'. "The Lost Isles" and "the Hidden Archipelago" would fit right in. Alternatively, follow history with things like "Cook Islands" and name it after whichever ship's captain first discovered it.

If there's natives, just whatever they would call it. Feel free to cop Polynesian languages and call it "Tahotu" or whatever other hack works; it won't be offensive unless you also make the natives offensive Polynesian caricatures and go over the top with ridiculous naming. If you want to be more authentic, pick a language that matches the vibe, read the phonology section on Wikipedia, and construct a name from that. But you don't need that degree of effort if linguistic consistency isn't important to you.

Pic related is an excerpt of a map I made for a now-dead campaign in the second style. Left nation's names were based on a butchered Malay; right was originally based on Malagasy but that got thrown out early and I made a few names ludicrously long for a laugh. After deciding on the different sounds they used and some basic phonotactics (e.g. the left nation has places often ending in '-ang'; right nation doesn't allow most consonant clusters) I just slammed syllables together until I was happy with the sound and called it a day.

In my experience, players only care if a name's pronounceable, whether that's "the Empire" or just "Wiltshire".

Humans, Goblins, Orcs, and Beastmen are various shades of chaotic while Elves, Dwarves, Gnomes, and Constructs are more ordered, think Barbarian Tribes vs Civilized City States. More specific breakdown would be:
Chaos
>Humans are the Germans, many fiefdoms ruled by whichever chieftain is the strongest who also take up mercenary work. They've fought for and against everybody at one point or another so they're warily welcome everywhere.
>Goblins are Gypsies, bringing trade, fun, and low-level crime to areas as they travel a circuit back to their home warrens with their loot. Also serve as the premier info-brokers since they get to everywhere eventually.
>Orcs are Huns, nomads wandering huge territories to avoid depleting an area completely with the occasional great horde sieging cities for fun and profit. Generally tolerated because they're the only ones crazy and strong enough to regularly go after the titanic monstrosities that also inhabit the steppes which would attack everybody else otherwise.
>Beastmen are Celts, confederated tribes led by druidic shamans in touch with nature/ancestor spirits who guard the woods. Pissed off the elves since they're closer to the wild Fae than the elves.
Order
>Elves are the Indians, with the caste-system as a result of them actually, confirmably being able to reincarnate and trying to make sure it goes smoothly upwards for everybody so they can return to being Fae
>Dwarves are the Byzantines, a continuation of the Roman Empire that fractured after a lot of internal fighting with a regression in tech due to loss of infrastructure to support it
>Gnomes are the Chinese, incredibly classist with a titanic bureacracy but also heavily meritocratic, they are the most populous race bar none but are extremely isolationist
>Constructs are the Italian Mercantile States, descendants the Roman Empire equivalent who used their preserved/rediscovered knowledge to gain the tech edge and expand trade

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
I always really like how magic is portrayed in Middle earth, but most popular systems hardly are reminiscent of it.

Not that this is suprising, The nature of magic in Hobbit/LotR is semi vague and seems to draw much of its effect from meaning and authority and the literal shifting of reality and perception thats hardly ever super overt and is not spelled out like a well defined hard magic system often prefers. But it feels very natural. like its more heightening/vaguening reality in an esoteric way. A dagger that inflicts some soul disease who's blade disapears in sunlight. The power to manipulate a river to flood in the shape of a charging cavalry. The infliction of supernatural terror and hope. changing the color of pipesmoke, etched runes that only respond to a set stimuli. Its like slightly pulling back the veil of what is and isnt and heightening aspects to a certain effect, not a stark spontantiously magical thing like a magic missle or a pool of acid from not. A lot of things could almost be taken as descriptors of fine qualities rather than being obviously magic, or mirrors the semi magic/semi description of actual myths where there is a vague area between the merely exceptional or exaggerated and the actually magical (like in many instances Excalibur may be seen as just an extremely well polished and fine sword, or maybe it does shine magical light).

So are there any systems that replicate this sort of subtle magic, or do you have any ideas how to implement such a thing that gives that sort of sense in a systematized way?

last_replies.com:
>>86771596
well, i dont know if “eariler” is the best way to put it. I think the muddying of the mundane and super mundane was often a fundamental part of “magic”. i mean, you can even see glimpses of that kind of thinking in romanticism of the 19th century, not to mention actual myths.
>>86772205
I dont think the nature of illusion was in question. just that it was often a promenent feature in the books.
